title: 105_s1907
content: REFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR WETLAND RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION EXPENSES: Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section on wetland restoration and conservation expenses. The tax code allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration, conservation, and easement expenses. The wetland restoration credit is based on the expenditures incurred by the taxpayer in a taxable year. The tax code allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration expenditures paid or incurred during the first 5 years of a qualified conservation agreement or qualified. The wetland conservation credit is an amount equal to the sum of the applicable percentage of the soil-specific Conservation Reserve Program rental rate, excluding expenditures required by law. The wetland conservation credit for a taxable year includes the applicable percentage of the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate for the taxpayer's qualified wetland under the Food Security Act of 1985, along with any compliance certification fees for the conservation agreement. The wetland conservation credit for a taxable year is determined by the applicable percentage based on the term of the qualified conservation agreement. The percentages range from 50% to 70% for agreements lasting 10 to 30 years. The wetland conservation credit is determined by the applicable percentage based on the term of the qualified conservation agreement, ranging from 50% to 70% for agreements lasting 10 to 30 years. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to receive an amount equal to the fair market value of qualified wetlands subject to a conservation easement. If a taxpayer elects the wetland easement credit for a taxable year, the wetland conservation credit for that year is zero. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to receive an amount equal to the fair market value of qualified wetlands subject to a conservation easement. The value is determined by a certified appraisal during the taxable year. An election under this subsection applies to the taxable year for which it is made. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to receive the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. An eligible taxpayer owns wetlands and surrounding farmland, entering into a conservation agreement or easement for the property. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. A qualified wetland is defined as wetland being converted to fully functioning condition through wetland restoration expenditures, determined under a conservation agreement or easement. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. The surrounding nonwetland must buffer water quality or wildlife habitat values associated with the wetland, with nonwetland acreage not exceeding 3 times the wetland acreage. Certain properties are excluded from this definition. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. The surrounding nonwetland must buffer water quality or wildlife habitat values associated with the wetland, with nonwetland acreage not exceeding 3 times the wetland acreage. Certain properties are excluded from this definition, including land receiving contract or easement payments from conservation programs. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. A qualified conservation agreement is an agreement by the eligible taxpayer with a governmental unit for a term of 10-30 years. The taxpayer agrees to comply with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland for 10-30 years and obtain certification every 5 years. The taxpayer must comply with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland for 10-30 years and obtain certification every 5 years. Compliance includes not using the wetland for agriculture and refraining from any activities that alter the wetland. The term 'qualified conservation easement' refers to an easement granted in perpetuity by the taxpayer to restrict the use of a wetland for agricultural production or development of built structures. Compliance with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland is necessary for 10-30 years, with certification required every 5 years. A conservation easement is an easement granted in perpetuity by the taxpayer to restrict the use of a qualified wetland for conservation purposes. No double benefit is allowed for expenses that are eligible for deduction or credit under other provisions of the tax code. The tax code prohibits claiming a credit for expenses covered by federal, state, or local programs. Married couples must file joint returns for this section to apply. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is updated. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998.
